body: This also includes `fd00::/8` which is typically used to address VPN peers with IPv6.

issue.title: Syncthing announces address of interface which is down

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Noticed this behaviour yesterday on my Windows machine. Syncthing seems to ignore if the interface is actually useable because it keeps announcing the manually configured IP of my winTUN interface.

It also announces a bunch of link-local 169.254.0.0/16 addresses but i can't ping any of them so i suspect that they are also from some interface but couldn't find anything in `ipconfig /all`

issue.title: unrelated ipv6 slaac privacy addresses are announced to the discovery service

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: New issues needed to be validated

issue.body:
The same issue is occurring with 2 hosts

Syncthing v1.20.3

Pop!_OS 22.04

Ipv6 (dhcpv6 & slaac w/stable and temporary privacy addresses) + Ipv4

I have configured syncthing to listen on the following: `tcp4://0.0.0.0:22000, quic4://0.0.0.0:22000, tcp6://[my:slaac:stable:privacy:address]:22000, quic6://[my:slaac:stable:privacy:address]:22000`

Yet when I look at https://discovery.syncthing.net/v2/?device=MY_DEVICE_ID I see my temporary slaac privacy address in the list.

I expect to see only addresses I have bound syncthing to, and my NAT ipv4 address. I do not expect unrelated ipv6 privacy addresses to be broadcast.

I assume the slaac temporary privacy address is added to the list because that is the address used to connect to the ipv6 discovery service? Is this intended? IPv6 does not have NAT, so I expect only bound addresses to be announced.

issue.title: Properly indicate whether a connection is "LAN" or not in the GUI

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
IPv6 LAN connections currently show up as WAN connections because they use public IPv6 addresses. We should check if the other address is in the same subnet to determine if it's a LAN connection.

Apart from the wrong connection type in the UI, this might also affect bandwidth limitation logic.

https://forum.syncthing.net/t/towards-better-connection-type-icons/19333/23

issue.title: "Try first" IPs for devices

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New features or improvements of some kind, as opposed to a problem (bug)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: New issues needed to be validated

issue.body:
### Include required information

I am trying to use syncthing with tailscale. Tailscale works well and I can ping everyone in my network using their MagicDNS names but Syncthing still insists in using a WAN relay. It's not a firewall issue because I added the tailscale interface in the trusted interfaces list. What I am looking for is a "try first" IPs approach where I pass the MagicDNS names of my hosts then Syncthing can try to connect to these IPs first before relying in any relays or hole punching and stuff.

issue.title: lib/connections: allow IPv6 ULA in discovery

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
### Purpose

Fixes #7456

The allowed IPv4 ranges are the same as before. But we now also accept IPv6 addresses in the ULA range `FC00::/7`. These addresses don't require an interface identifier and are roughly equivalent to the IPv4 private ranges.

Typical usecases:

* VPN interface IPs: Wireguard, OpenVPN, Tailscale, ...
* fixed IPv6 LAN addressing while the provider assigns a dynamic prefix. e.g used by pihole

https://cs.opensource.google/go/go/+/refs/tags/go1.21.0:src/net/ip.go;l=146

### Testing

I checked the output of https://discovery.syncthing.net/?device=xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx and my local `fd00::` IPs were listed.
